unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked why healthcare is such a mess in India and how identifiers play a role. Buckle up, folks, because this is going to be a wild ride!
normalised: Okay, so someone asked why healthcare is such a mess in India and how identifiers play a role. Buckle up, folks, because this is going to be a wild ride!

unnormalised: First off, let's talk about identifying patients. Right now, it's like the Wild West. You walk into a clinic, and they might give you a new MRN (Medical Record Number) that's totally separate from the one you got at the last hospital. It's like having multiple identities – are you Rakesh Kumar, or Rakhesh Kumarr, or simply R. Kumar? The poor doctor is trying to figure out your allergies while battling a database full of doppelgangers! Then they assign you with a UHID, lets say its is 1234567890, and hope for the best.
normalised: First off, let's talk about identifying patients. Right now, it's like the Wild West. You walk into a clinic, and they might give you a new M-R-N (Medical Record Number) that's totally separate from the one you got at the last hospital. It's like having multiple identities – are you Rakesh Kumar, or Rakhesh Kumarr, or simply R. Kumar? The poor doctor is trying to figure out your allergies while battling a database full of doppelgangers! Then they assign you with a U-H-I-D, let's say it is one two three four five six seven eight nine zero, and hope for the best.

unnormalised: Think about it: you go to AIIMS Delhi with your Aadhaar number (let’s say 9876-5432-1012) and they still make you fill out a form with every address you've ever lived at. Why?! Isn't the point of Aadhaar to... identify you? Apparently not enough for the medical field. It's like the government is playing hide-and-seek with your medical history.
normalised: Think about it: you go to A-I-I-M-S Delhi with your Aadhaar number (let’s say nine eight seven six dash five four three two dash one zero one two) and they still make you fill out a form with every address you've ever lived at. Why?! Isn't the point of Aadhaar to... identify you? Apparently not enough for the medical field. It's like the government is playing hide-and-seek with your medical history.

unnormalised: Then there's the insurance side of things. You have your policy number (ICICI Lombard says it’s something like: IL/HLTH/2024/00001). Good luck remembering that thing when you’re doubled over in pain! Plus, different insurance companies might have different ways of identifying the same procedure. One calls it "Appendectomy, Laparoscopic," another calls it "Laparoscopic Appendectomy," and yet another just scribbles "Appendix Gone!" It's a free-for-all.
normalised: Then there's the insurance side of things. You have your policy number (I-C-I-C-I Lombard says it’s something like: I-L slash H-L-T-H slash two thousand and twenty four slash zero zero zero zero one). Good luck remembering that thing when you’re doubled over in pain! Plus, different insurance companies might have different ways of identifying the same procedure. One calls it "Appendectomy, Laparoscopic," another calls it "Laparoscopic Appendectomy," and yet another just scribbles "Appendix Gone!" It's a free-for-all.

unnormalised: Imagine your doc trying to submit your claim. They fill out form A, B, & C. He fills out the insurance details as Policy No.: 0987654321. God forbid if they put a space in the wrong place or misread a number 8 as a 3. Your claim gets rejected faster than you can say "medical inflation." Next thing you know you get a bill for Rs. 50,000 and they send a reminder every week.
normalised: Imagine your doc trying to submit your claim. They fill out form A, B, and C. He fills out the insurance details as Policy No.: zero nine eight seven six five four three two one. God forbid if they put a space in the wrong place or misread a number eight as a three. Your claim gets rejected faster than you can say "medical inflation." Next thing you know you get a bill for rupees fifty thousand and they send a reminder every week.

unnormalised: What we really need is a standardized system. Something like a national health ID (NHID) that actually works. Linked to Aadhaar, sure, but maybe with a separate, easier-to-remember number too. Something like a universal patient identifier where the first 4 digits could indicate your year of birth like 1985, then followed by a unique sequence -1234-1234, for all to use.
normalised: What we really need is a standardized system. Something like a national health I-D (N-H-I-D) that actually works. Linked to Aadhaar, sure, but maybe with a separate, easier-to-remember number too. Something like a universal patient identifier where the first four digits could indicate your year of birth like one thousand nine hundred and eighty five, then followed by a unique sequence - one two three four - one two three four, for all to use.

unnormalised: The only way we can bring some sanity to the chaos is if everyone gets on the same page. Until then, be prepared to carry a suitcase full of medical records and ID cards to every appointment.
normalised: The only way we can bring some sanity to the chaos is if everyone gets on the same page. Until then, be prepared to carry a suitcase full of medical records and I-D cards to every appointment.

unnormalised: So, next time you're filling out your tenth medical form, remember you’re not alone. We're all in this wonderfully disorganized healthcare system together. Laugh, cry, and maybe prepone your next doctor's appointment because this will never get sorted soon!
